question.name: 19.2.2.1 Applying the method of separation of variables to ODEs
question.questiontext:
Applying the method of separation of variables to ODEs

Example

Use the method of separation of variables to solve the differential equation \[ \dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=\dfrac{3x^2}{y}.\]

Solution

The equation already has the form \[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=f(x)g(y)\] where\[f(x)=3x^2\quad \text{and} \quad g(y)=1/y.\] Dividing both sides by \(g(y)\) we find \[y\dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = 3x^2. \] Integrating both sides with respect to \(x\) gives \[ \int y\dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} \,\mathrm{d}x = 3x^2 \,\mathrm{d}x\] that is \[ \int y\ \mathrm{d}y = \int 3x^2 \, \mathrm{d}x.\] Note that the left-hand side is an integral involving just \(y\); the right-hand side is an integral involving just \(x\). After integrating both sides with respect to the stated variables we find \[ \dfrac{1}{2} y^2 = x^3 + c \] where \(c\) is a constant of integration. (You might think that there would be a constant on the left-hand side too. You are quite right but the two constants can be combined into a single constant and so we need only write one.) We now have a relationship between \(y\) and \(x\) as required. Often it is sufficient to leave your answer in this form but you may also be required to obtain an explicit relation for \(y\) in terms of \(x\). In this particular case \[y^2=2x^3+2c\] so that \[y=\pm \sqrt{2x^3+2c} .\]
